YouTube's Content ID system IS broken - at least when it comes to classical music. The system is incapable of discerning one recording of a classical work from another. This leads to endless wrong claims when an original recording is uploaded by a performer. Sometimes one sample will be claimed by several different licenses, as if the ID system is willing to let anyone ask for the same exact slice of your ad revenue. It's a horrible mess, especially when one licence company has an automated directive to restrict a video instead of just claiming revenue. In essence, the system allows companies to falsely claim revenue from an original creator's work, and even shut it down entirely, all without any legal grounds. That is a broken system.

You skimmed over the DMCA abuse, which is rampant on YouTube. I don't mean "it's questionable whether this is infringement or fair use, so they're just filing it because they genuinely think it's not fair use"... I mean people filing DMCA claims on content *they clearly do not own the rights to* for nefarious purposes, because YouTube's system does not handle this well. It also doesn't require the same diligence that the law requires in terms of consideration given to fair use. So there are now companies that exist solely to go around filing DMCA claims at anyone who includes the likeness of someone as a form of censoring criticism even if the likeness is an image or video that the person *does not have rights to* . This is not what DMCA is for, that's what a privacy complaint is for, but the DMCA is used because YouTube provides it as an automated way to "take revenue from a popular creator, or remove a video you don't like." That's not the purpose of DMCA, but that's what YouTube provides, which is strictly worse than DMCA and not in the spirit of copyright law. That is *fundamentally and completely broken* and you ignored it.

The problem with things like ContentID is that it does not at all work in classical music. You can very often see an automatic claim for a recording because a different recording is in the database.
But even if it is someone uploading or using a recording it is absolutely infuriating, especially since YouTube does not offer an option to refute this claim (the only option is to say: All content is mine). If you are using some recording, you might well be okay with the label taking some revenue, but you surely are not wanting some completely unrelated label profiting from this, because they have a recording of the same piece in the CID database.
This get’s even worse when live broadcasts of concerts are put on YouTube by an Orchestra, an organizer or some radio channel, and you get a f***ing claim for using some recording.
And then there’s the thing with old recordings, that do not have property rights anymore. You basically can legally do anything with such recordings, as long as the compositions are in public domain. But then you get things like Naxos who transfer old recordings, and since those are then in the ContentID database, YouTube will assume that Naxos has the rights to this recording.
So basically ContentID should not be used for classical music. It just doesn’t work, and make YouTube take part in a hugh violation of copyright themselves, because they are making money (or helping others make money) for claiming the copyright for something that they do not have.

YouTube is broken. A few years ago, I used music with the right license. A company flagged the music as a copyright infringement. But the music they claimed was totally different. I got them to drop the case and say they made a mistake. But it means work for me for clearing a false claim. It was clearly a case of gross negligence in fact checking the claim. I could have sued in a local court (we have a law that nullifies the notion of choice of court). But it means wasting more time and money. YouTube should add in their TOS a clause that a company filing a claim should pay 100$ each time where they get their money back only if the case is properly documented and proven. This is where our governments and The Law completely fails us. When creating a law that is suppose to have final say over what is legal and what isnt, especially when it comes to something as simple as using a video or a piece of music, there should be NO grey area. It should be cut and dry simple. Having those grey areas is what allows big corporations to effectively screw over the little guy, even if they did NOTHING wrong all because they can't afford to pay the legal fees in order to defend themselves.  They have effectively locked people's ability to defend themselves behind a Pay wall. So it doesn't matter if your 100% in the right, did everything the correct way and the corporation that is sueing you is just being greedy bastards trying to literally STEAL your money.  If you can't afford to fight it in court, at best you just have to  remove the content you depend on for money and at worst you end up paying out a lot of money to a corporation that legally doesn't deserve it. The current copyright laws have made a modern day version of highway robbery a VERY easy thing to do and for large companies a lot of the times a VERY lucrative business practice that some businesses are completely centered around. This end up leaving smaller individual content creators with no way of defending themselves.  So regardless if this is how it is, it NEEDS to change. Governments around the world are not changing with the times. They can no longer afford to let laws sit around unchanged for 10 years, let alone for 50 or 100 years like they use to. Technology and our society are moving forward at a break neck speed, and the law needs to keep up or risk becoming obsolete or even creating worse problems then they were created to fix.

Honestly, I don’t have any inherent problem with ContentID under current copyright laws. Yes, it makes a lot of mistakes, but that’s inevitable, really, especially at this scale. My main problems are with the appeals process (which is generally opaque and often not done very well, frequently deferring to the claimant rather than the appellant, even for manual claims that are clearly fair use, public domain, or not owned by the claimant) and with the lack of consequences for obvious abuse (like allowing clearly public domain material such as white noise to be claimed without any consequences at all). There’s also the fact that, even if the claim gets overturned, any revenue during that period goes to the claimant (if they allowed ads but just wanted the revenue) and the YouTuber gets nothing for that time period. Similarly, I wouldn’t mind the copyright strikes system (since it’s mandated by the DMCA anyway) if there were consequences for making too many frivolous claims, but that’s a legal issue rather than a YouTube issue.

And that’s the key issue: ContendID isn’t the real problem; copyright law is. I also hate it when copyright maximalists use ContentID to either claim that US copyright law mandates filters or that upload filters can work and are feasible, both of which are untrue.

For classical music performances, Content ID is broken.

Being that a piano sonata from Beethoven, or a violin concerto by Tchaikovsky has been recorded thousands of times, it is inevitable that some seconds of your own performance have similarity to 1 or more recordings. Then, you automatically get a claim (or more) and some random Polish recording company get to place advertisements on your videos.

Once you cycle through your videos and find a claim,  you disputed and 1 month later it is removed but, by then, another of your performances has been claimed... It is stressing.

It is usual to find a video of an elder pianist sharing his performance of a classical piece, and see that it has been claimed multiple times. It gets ridiculous to the point that in the description of the video, shows the content to be from multiple pianists across different ages, nationalities and recording houses.

I think with orchestral music is worse. I suspect the Content ID system has big tolerances and is flawed when judging over complex sounds.

One important keyword is "commercially," so none of this applies to memes made and shared among a private group (say in a chat) for purely comedic purposes. Moreover, if anything like this did become an issue, the violation of privacy by exposing a chat's messages would be far worse than the violation of copyright.

"Horrible gamer children"? Look the only time you could make an argument for streaming negatively impacting video game sales, is if we're talking about a visual novel (but that opens the can of worms about whether or not VNs can really be called games). Or maybe if your game is absolutely terrible but your marketing department is great and you only want to be a "one and done" type of company. Now as far as streamers being able to earn money off of it, that's a bit more debatable.

I run my church's Youtube channel and we've had a ridiculous number of Content ID matches for our own performances of public domain songs. I'm tempted to name and shame the companies who have clearly gone to the effort to tell Content ID to look for these songs and flag anything that uses that melody line.

EDIT: You know what, I don't care any more. The following organisations have knowingly used the Content ID system to make false copyright claims on Public Domain songs:

- ICE_CS
- Capitol CMG Publishing
- Adorando Brazil
- Sony ATV Publishing
- ECAD_CS
- LatinAutor
- IRICOM
- TEOSTO
- TONO_CS
- BUMA CS
- VCPMC_CS
- KODA_CS
- AdShare (Publishing)
- Concord Music Publishing

The problem is that humans.have a natural urge to be selfishly greedy, which is why there exists ownership of resources—property. Given the existential risk involved in physically fighting each other to acquire ownership of a resource, we have come to impose upon ourselves the "civil" alternative we call "trade". This necessarily imposes upon ourselves some kind of set of governing rules, to wit, an economic system, which necessarily puts price stickers on everything. Since we each have only a finite amount of resources (such as money) with which to trade at any given time, an economic system is a rationing system, allocating resources according to some or other criterion. (Capitalism, for example, allocates resources fundamentally according to the individual's innate ability to acquire them, which is unfair given that innate ability is unchosen, unalterable and personally unique, resulting in inequality of personal outcomes. Capitalism is also inefficient; for example, rival pharmacological companies not sharing commercially sensitive research—hiding research-discovery pieces of the same treatment jigsaw from each other—resulting in unnecessary duplication of effort and precluding the efficiency which is the building upon each other's research and discoveries. "USSR communist-type" economies stifle endeavour as the people are allocated resources equally no matter what any individual's productive output. *All* economic systems are unfair and inefficient, stifling progress, by definition.) We don't need economic systems—they're not like gravity. Let's abandon them.

I feel that you were a bit disingenuous. 95% of the time, when someone says a video was falsely flagged it falls into one of these categories:

1. A third party who does NOT own the rights to the content in the video claims the video to steal the youtuber's revenue. Youtube's system gives said person total control and zero accountability. This is almost ALWAYS what people refer to by Youtube's copyright claim system being broken.
2. The creator of a work that is being critiqued claims the video and takes it down to silence valid criticism.
3. A troll/protestor claims a video to take it down because they think it would be funny, or because they disagree with the contents of the video.
4. A company strategically claims a video they do not own any content in, because it had better searchability than their video (SEGA did this to videos that beat their Sonic trailer a while ago)


Number 5, "I stole content to use it in a way that was not review or critique of the source material in any way and got flagged" is a very small subset of complaints, and to characterize them as being the main representation of the "falsely flagged" complaint is just wrong.

Also consider:
Video games from 15 years ago may not run on a modern PC, as games from 1995 didn't always work on PCs from 2005.
The PS1 has a huge library that cannot be played at all without disc hunting (and since emulation is legally grey, possibly finding a real example of a PS1 or PS2, which don't work on modern TVs without expensive adapters) ever since emuparadise got taken down.

Old arcade boxes from the 80s, do not run on any modern hardware without the MAME software which is emulation, and distributing the software is copyright infringement.

IMO, video game copyright should last 15 years tops for these reasons. Getting gaming history to work on modern machines is hard enough, let alone navigating it legally.

99.9% of the issues people have with copyright comes from a single source: the companies. The rest is from the greedy assholes, sure. But those both share the same key identity: greed. How to make the copyright system better? You don't really need to change it in any significant way, just demolish the corporative hold on it. Take away the possibility of having copyright rights from companies. Destroy the ability to transfer the rights to your work to somebody else. What you made is yours, forever and unalienably Not the company you had worked for, not your children that didn't even existed when you had created this, _yours._ There's myriad options to allow other still use your work without them going "Hey, _I'm_ the author and owner now."Sadly we live in a world when media corporations have more income than the GDP of quite a lot of countries. So it's an already lost fight. They will bribe the politicians with millions of dollars (or, as the americants like to phrase it, "lobby their interests") to make sure they retain the hold on the souls of the creators. Some creators and copyright holders (notably most of  those that talk about 'intellectual property' in a non-sarcastic manner) seem to want copyright to be indefinite (which... Would be very damaging)
But we're already at term lengths so long that it might as well be indefinite for all practical purposes.


Because of that, the very idea of 'public domain' has largely lost it's meaning in any realistic sense.
And copyright laws don't serve their original intended purpose when copyright lasts a VERY long time.


What little research there is on the subject of how long copyright protection should last given that original intent...
Well, it points to several issues;
- Firstly, within the margin of error for the research done, copyright terms should last no longer than 35 years, and may need to be as short as 7 years to have the original intended effect.
- Secondly, and more problematically, how long copyright protection lasts should be getting SHORTER over time, as more copyrighted works come into existence... (as, in a strict sense, the more works exist, the less value each has individually)


Trouble is, of course, that lobbying tends to have the opposite effect. Copyright terms keep being extended, and once they are a particular length, undoing it and going back to a shorter length appears nigh impossible.


A LOT of the most egregious problems we are currently facing would largely go away if copyright terms could go back to being maybe a decade or two, not measurable in more than a century...


But alas, the odds of that happening, given that the changes to the law over time have all seemingly gone in the opposite direction?
Well, that's just not very likely is it?
And it doesn't help that the primary beneficiaries of the current system are not individual creators, but large media conglomerates whose primary interest is gaining the rights to as many things as they possibly can...

What's worse than copyright law, is patent law. They're both intellectual property and should hold the same terms. 
Both should cease at death of the creator, or until any license agreement at death expires, or 20 years if owned or filed by a company. Current patent laws limit protection to 20 years, even though far more time and money is put into creating an invention than a book or photo. A photo can be created in a fraction of a second, a book in a week, and costs only a few hundred dollars to copyright if you pay someone to do it. A patent takes sometimes decades of work and costs thousands of dollars to get a patent.

What we have currently is the Copyright System of Theseus. It has kept the name and shape of its original genesis, but all parts are so twisted beyond comprehension that the originators of it would not recognize it.

I am an illustrator. I know copyright is broken because since about 2005 I have not been able to retain copyright on any of my original work. Prior to that customers would pay me to make a custom artwork that they licensed for use in a particular work. However at some point lawyers decided that transfer of all rights would be boilerplate in every contract. So I do not, can not, retain rights to my own work in any sense. Theoretically putting my work in an online portfolio would be stealing from a major international publisher with many lawyers who could bankrupt me in minutes. This is not a symmetrical business relationship. I have no say in the terms dictated by the publisher.

Intellectual property rights have become a mechanism by which huge multi-national corporations collect all rights and honestly, as things stand, we would all be better off scrapping IPR and starting over than continuing as we have been.

The world's  copyright *system* isn't broken, because it doesn't really really have one. It has copyright *laws*, and those are just being applied. Badly - and I'd say sometimes maliciously - and they need to be reformed, but that doesn't mean the system itself it broken.


Youtube does have a copyright system, and although parts of it do work, other parts are definitely broken. That  three strikes policy is far more insidious than this video claims. If you use someone else's material when you shouldn't, your video should definitely be demonitised. If you believe you are in the right and dispute three of those claims, your entire channel is demonetised until the conflict is resolved. And getting your money back for that period? Good luck.


Also, copyright law is not the reason James Bond movies aren't being made by anyone else. It's trademark law, and I don't really have a problem with that. Anything produced 50 years ago should be in the public domain, but tthat does not mean you can just make your own version.

It seems to me there's a bit of overthinking here; see, copyrights and patents are legal attempts to address IP in two qualities: monetary compensation and authorship recognition. How is the worst possible way we could rip off someone else on account of these two things? Answer: by picking up someone else's work, labeling it of your own creation, and making a profit out of it - that's a form of fraud. Sure, we can discuss the more nuanced cases, but basically anything that deviates from this general idea in an essential way, is spurious and prolly motivated by vested interests - like the given example of the eternal lobbying of Big Bucks Co., Ltd., who wants to bank on the "Happy Copyright Strike Day" song till the coming of Ragnarök...

I strongly disagree that copyright should only last for 50 years, dead stop. Tom also makes the claims that this would effect a tiny proportion of creators, and dismisses royalties as a bad retirement plan. This is all wrong. Authors often make serialised works that carry on original situations, characters, and world-building over many decades. Imagine the legal headache if the copyright ran out for the founding work of an ongoing series of science fiction novels or films while the original author was still active. Tom is also selectively forgetting that educational works, like texts and audiovisual series are added to and supplemented over many decades by single authors as a life's work (especially in the case of university texts).That is not a small category of authors by any means. Often such work is done with the expectation not just of retirement but also that their families who sacrificed many hours on behalf of the creative work will be looked after. So it's not as simple as it may sound here.

When it comes to how much a law should be enforced there are two types of errors: under-enforcement and over-enforcement. The cost of over-enforcement is easily seen, which is why we hear about unjust take downs all the time. But the cost of under-enforcement is an unseen cost: it's all the movies and pictures and songs that have never been made because it's simply too hard to make money off of them when someone can just steal it consequence free. If you want to be serious about how the law should be or what YouTube should do about it, you have to take both of these problems into consideration, and not just focus on the examples that you read in the news.

it IS broken for a simple reason:
Content ID almost works. It would work with a very simple addition: If youtube would require a fee (similar to courts), if you loose a claim. That way companies would stop spamming claims (that are mostly against fair use) automatically, which is the real problem.
A company would not risk claiming 35 videos with 10 seconds of "fair use" regalated material in each (like a snippet of a song playing on a radio, when a person just wants to show that radio works), if  25 would dispute the claim. Even with just a fee of 10$, that would mean a loss of 250$ for the company.
And 250$ can not be that easily made back with the 10 remaining legit videos.
So those copyright claim companies would have to start using people who know what a legit claim is, instead of bots that should not exist. This is what breaks the system.
You cant go to a court and sue 30 persons either. if 25 of them won the court, you would have to pay the court fees, and likely be backrupt.

Wow. Very sensible. I've always thought copyright should remain at 50 years (it still does for Crown copyright in the UK). As an author myself I'd love it if it was 20 years after date of death. Why should my distant descendants benefit from my hard work?  Orphaned works are the worst. I know of several cases where things that were published in *the 1890s* are still in copyright because the authors of those works lived very long lives and died in the 1950s - it shouldn't require researching the family history of someone to deduce who the rights holders are. I got a claim on one of my songs, but the song the copyright owner said I used doesn’t seem to exist online, and the claiming company doesn’t have any online presence. Furthermore I used two Splice samples I purchased the rights to. The samples are licensed non-exclusively meaning I can’t submit my derivative work to the Content ID database, but that also means that other derivative works can’t claim ownership of the sample used in my track. They rejected my dispute of the claim and I’m now in the appeal stage waiting for their response. 

I don’t reject the copyright system because its how I make money from music, but I wish the process wasn’t so hands-off and unregulated. I’m confident that once my claim reaches an objective third party then the claim will be dropped, but it seems that if Content ID makes a mistake or if someone gets ineligible work into the Content ID database, then anyone can file a fraudulent claim if given the opportunity by a misfire of the ID algorithm, and a third party doesn’t get involved until after you appeal a takedown order after months of disputes and appeals. And I’m not talking about fair-use like reviews or background music, I don’t do that content and don’t care, its about musical works, source material and third party moderation of claims.
Just don’t use other people’s ideas. Simple.

Sorry Tom, but it's easy to claim YouTube's copyright system isn't broken when you haven't been the victim of blatantly fraudulent claims which were left up for the maximum duration YouTube allows before responding. And when you have a channel large enough that not only do you pass YouTube's new restrictions on who is allowed to make money on the platform (I used to be, but then a year or two ago they decided "stuff small creators" and removed me and all other small guys), but *huge* enough that if you did run into any problems, you could raise enough of a fuss to get it fixed.


I've had videos of myself playing public domain music (Beethoven) receive _multiple_ copyright claims from _multiple_ different organisations. In one case, the claim was on _the wrong piece of music!_ I played the Pathetique, it claimed I was playing Moonlight.


So yes, the world's copyright system _is_ broken. But that doesn't negate the fact that YouTube allows fraudulent entities to abuse its Content ID left and right.

I've got a couple opinions on this now, after watching the video. Feel free to criticise me, 'cause I'm just some 17 year old kid writing this on the toilet, so I'm obviously not the smartest guy around.

1. I feel like the UN should work together to form new copyright laws internationally. Considering small creators, large companies, and everything in-between. 
Obviously, this isn't very feasible, that would be MASSIVELY expensive, and there are other, more important things going on in the world than copyright. But in an ideal world, that is what I would like to see. A new, built from the ground-up UN enforced copyright system, for all countries in the UN.

2. Smaller businesses should be given some sort of compensation to go up against larger businesses. 
I don't know if this applies outside of Australia, or if I've been taught an over-simplified version of it, but in business class, we've been taught there are 5 kinds of businesses. Sole trader, Partnership, Private Limited Companies, Public Listed Companies, and social enterprises. If a Sole Trader or Partnership goes up against, say, Disney in court, that is extremely unfair. How can the correct outcome be met, and justice upheld, if Disney is gonna have WAY better lawyers? On top of that, I don't think it's particularly fair for social enterprises to be affected by copyright law, as they aren't even looking to make a profit (I don't know if there are already laws around this, I'm just splurging out my opinions into a youtube comment). 
Now, this still creates issues for youtube. Who is the business? Is it youtube themselves, or the actual content creators? Or is it some sort of a mixture of the two? But I think someone smarter than me could probably clear that up.

I probably just said a lot of really stupid stuff, so go ahead and lay into me. I'd rather get cleared up on how this actually works than remain ignorant.

To answer the question of "fair use", simply ask yourself whether your usage will lose the Copyright owner revenue (cause financial damage). If your use does lose the owner money, then you've almost certainly broken Copyright law.

This isn't about your making money from someone else's Copyright material, it's about whether your earnings are money that should rightly have come to the Copyright owner. 

The key question is whether your use is affecting the revenues of the Copyright owner.

Frankly, that photographer's "opinion" should be the law. The thing with ideas (intelectual property) is that once you share one with someone else, yours is not lost, it's still there. And that other person has their own personal interpretation of the same idea. You should legally own your idea, of course. But this right should stop, just like any other right, where somebody else's right to hold their own idea begins. Simple. Reinterpreting a song (even for profit)  would remain always legal, people doing it for free shouldn't even be bothered with this stuff, however reusing somebody else interpretation or original song for profit should remain illegal. It's completely unacceptable that the state helps these big companies preserve their monopoly on content at the expense of the tax payers or, worse, that the state helps to legally pursue people who aren't making a profit at all.

Tom: A neglected aspect of IP.  Taxpayers fund the government departments that protect the social contract of IP.  The other side of that deal is that at the end of some time the works taxpayers are paying to protect will become public property for their use.   The value of government protection is very, very high.  How high?  Financial test: if IP owners had to pay 100% of the cost of defending their IP, would they make profits?  (Answer: no).   In a fair system, those who fund IP protection would set the amount of time they were willing to pay before they received benefit.  So yes, the world's IP system is corrupt because the people funding it clearly have no voice in making the deal.

While much of this video is great, it misses the reality for small creators of the AUTOMATED systems.  They often pick up uses that NO human would challenge - thus creating unfair claims.  For example, I had a video of an RC helicopter flight copyright struck due to a reflection of a tv-show being played in a window that was visible for just a handful of frames with no audio.  It was hardly visible, and certainly unrelated to the video - and nothing a HUMAN lawyer nor viewer would have noticed.  I don't make a career on YouTube, and it is an unacceptable grab for systems like these.  If we are going to be judged by AI systems there must be more transparency, more content creator control, and the ability to challenge claims fairly and test with these same tools.  Not all impacted videos are 'reaction videos' or other potentially actually copyright-infringing videos.

The *point* of copyright is to encourage artists *to build the public domain*.

This mistaken view is precisely why we are in, as Pogo put it, "de mess we is in".

And yes, you say that next, but I feel like the order is critical to fixing the problem; if the people trying to fix the problem aren't prioritizing those two goals in the right order, we'll end up with what we already have.

It's my belief that the majority of what can be copyrighted, shouldn't be able to be copyrighted. If something can be copied or recreated with minimal effort, does it really deserve to be protected? If a digital file can be duplicated an infinite amount of times, is it really worth protecting? I don't think so. Argue what you want that this would be harmful to the internet, music or film industries, or whatever else, if your only means of protecting something from being copied is a lawyer saying "you just can't" then whatever you have isn't worth being protected.

For as long as a party can claim an *entire video and all its revenue* because they own a small (or substantially altered) portion of it, I outright refuse to let it stand as an acceptable affair, even in the light of the world's *entirely* broken, due-for-almost-complete-replacement copyright system.
Also, yes, fair use should be *massively* expanded for non-commercial use, and any sort of compensation or penal action on the side of the defendant should be void. Cease-and-desist should be the maximum damage that can be incurred.

Non-commercial derivative works with substantial alterations should simply be fair use, and something like Youtube's content-ID system certifying the substantial alteration should be enough to close the case in favour of the defendant, or at least shift the burden of proof.

On a wider note, the system is broken in more ways: People shouldn't need to worry about making a living. If capitalism can't provide free housing, for example, capitalism is a failure that needs to be abolished. I believe it can provide free housing, so I think capitalism doesn't need to be abolished.

 To me, the way a system works out for the bottom 10% of society is categorical to my judgement of it. If it fails in that regard, the system gets an F.

The bit on the copyrights for music failed to address one of the most infuriating parts of the YT ID system for classical fans, which is that Youtube often cannot tell the difference between a performance of a (well out of compositional copyright) classical piece that you performed and filmed yourself and thus own the rights to, versus the many professional recordings of the piece owned by UMG and Warner and EMI and whoever else, and will claim your performance as one of those recordings. This happens a lot more often than with covers of modern songs because a lot of classical pieces are written in a way that encourages fairly consistent performances, not putting your own spin on it the way cover artists like to - but each person's performance is still their own individual work, and YouTube's search-and-destroy bot is very bad at recognizing the little details that make them unique.

I broadly agree except for one thing which I think doesn't get enough attention. The whole point of copyright is to provide incentive for artists to create. Changing copyright protections for works that already exist doesn't make any sense, because they were already created. Changing the incentives later isn't going to retroactively change art in the past. The Sonny Bono law extended copyright protections for existing works, and I think that was wrong or at least misguided. However, it would similarly be unfair to creators to curtail the protections of works created since that law. Those creators put effort and resources into their work with the legal expectation that it would be protected for a specific amount of time. Shortening that time on them would be wrong.

I think that one of the problems is that the US and UK both use intentionally vague language in their statutes, meaning that contracts must be long and complex, as the English Common Law legal system allows for statutes to be overturned or altered by judges.

What they COULD do is move over to the Roman Civil Law system that’s used in Continental Europe and have highly detailed language in the statute, with simpler contracts. The downside, however, is that the “innocent until proven guilty” standard in criminal cases gets flip-flopped, so doing this would uproot one of the US’s core national values.

Gifs are transformative. The original content is a movie, TV show or standup routine. The transformative work is a 3 second video loop used to convey a single emotion or reaction. Nobody is looking at a gif of baby Yoda and saying "oh, well I guess I don't need to see The Mandalorian now", so it does not make any difference to the original work's sales. THAT is the legal test for whether work is transformative. It has nothing to do with the method of copying the work but the actual effect of copying it. If you can't prove your damages you have no standing for a civil suit. This is solely an issue of a money fight with lawyers where a small internet company has not enough money to win the fight.

Intellectual property is a contract between creators and the public to pretend ideas are property (they aren't) for a short period of time in exchange for advancing the public good and putting those ideas into the public domain. As long as creators are lobbying for longer and longer terms, such that nothing is going into public domain, the public receives no benefit, thus making the original contract null and void and intellectual property no longer a thing. Shame that it's in the interest of judging that issue to ignore that little detail and continue extending copyright every time there's a risk that Mickey Mouse might become public domain.

Although this video has probably swayed my opinion towards content ID, one part that is still thoroughly broken about it is that reviewers basically cannot make money from advertisements, nor can they demonetize the video, as they will always automatically get flagged and the appeal process is not quick enough.  I would say, if a YouTuber has consistently shown to understand and adhere to fair use, it is extremely unethical for YouTube to still automatically assume it is infringement and hand over 95% of the profits to the company.

There's two ways I can think of to fix this, and I think they should both be implemented.  One, reviewers who consistently win appeals should not be flagged automatically.  Two, upon a won appeal, YouTube should retroactively give the profits to the YouTuber.  YouTube can then easily get their money back from the copyright holder by withholding some of the ad revenue that they get from other sources.

There's one way in which YouTube's copyright system IS broken and DOES NOT NEED TO BE.

Let's say someone levels a copyright strike against your video.  You're convinced the claimant is wrong, and that your video doesn't violate copyright.  You provide your full legal contact information so the claimant can sue you directly, and file a counter-claim with YouTube.

Under America's DMCA, YouTube has the right to say "Okay, we're putting your video back up unless the claimant can prove he's taking legal action against you.  According to the DMCA's Safe Haven laws, so long as we provide your legal information to the claimant, YouTube can no longer be sued over your video.  We wash our hands of you."

But that's NOT WHAT YOUTUBE DOES.  Instead, they REVIEW your counter-claim and DECIDE FOR THEMSELVES whether THEY think you violated copyright or not.  There is no lawyer involved, certainly no judge, just a quick bureaucratic yes-or-no decision.  If some yahoo who got assigned to answer the counter-claims today thinks you violated copypright because his bowels are acting up, YouTube will REJECT YOUR COUNTER-CLAIM and keep your video disabled (and keep the copyright strike against you).

Transformative critique: why _should_ a songwriter from the eighties still be able to profit from their song if a lifesaving patent from the 90's is no longer worth a dime? If anything, copyright law should last a lesser amount of time.

Additionally, the core problem with the current system is the burden of proof. I don't have to prove that you've violated copyright law in order to copyright strike your video. I only need the barest of an excuse. From a legal standpoint, that's backward. People are supposed to be innocent until proven guilty. If we enforced that standard, then companies probably wouldn't bother going after small channels, and peoples' behavior wouldn't need to change very much.

One point I'm really missing here. Companies infringe on individuals all the time. Over 10 years ago my amateur photo, published on my own website (we had those in past decade), was used to illustrate an article by one of the largest news portals in my country. They just cut the picture so my signature was removed. I politely wrote them. I didn't want money or takedown, I just wished to be mentioned as an author. The response wasn't even in legalese. It wasn't in PR jargon. It was just "you can sue us, sincerely..." - in those exact words. Since then I had dozens of pictures stolen in less impressive fashion. I had a web design stolen. With an exception of one identity theft for dating site, all those infringements were intentional and corporate. I know a few content creators, mainly photographers and graphic designers, all of them have such stories. And there is even less defense against that than it is against copyright strikes.
I believe we need sth that will never happen, because of money: leveling of field. What UK did was a step in right direction, but it needs to go far deeper. And another thing we need is absolute precedence of individual creator rights over corporate property copyright. Without that corporate entities will always have an upper hand.

Another patch for the system: Require both sides to have the same legal expertise, and restrict it to what the poorest party can afford. If Joe Know-Nothing with $0.50 to his name and zero knowledge of the law is getting sued by Disney, then Disney has to be represented by someone with $0.50 to their name and zero knowledge of the law, too.

Sure, copyright laws are not great but, that's not the issue here. People aren't mad over the law. They aren't mad because they think that YouTube is doing anything illegal with their copyright system even if they say otherwise. What they are actually mad at is the morality. The morality of the brutal power disparity between individual content producers and large companies wielding the law against them which in this case is actually YouTube's fault. YouTube and other companies like ride share companies like the ride sharing apps Lyft and Uber make their money by "employing" millions of people ("independent contractors") that produce their product (videos or transportation) without fair compensation.  I'm sure sometimes as a percentage of profit the pay is appropriate but that ignores the fact that by divorcing themselves of any sort of responsibility that traditional companies would have over their employees allows them to sell their products at a rate that would out-compete any competitor that tried to provide a similar service with even a modicum of employee support. The idea that YouTube is just an innocent bystander enforcing the law while benefiting immensely from the work of millions of people who they do not train or provide legal support for is wrong. YouTube's parent company Google (or I guess technically Alphabet) is one of the largest in the world and the only reason I can imagine that can't provide some level of support to the people that are it's bread winners is that it's fundamental structure is exploitative. So on the one hand they are at fault for not providing support if they can or on the other they cannot make money without exploiting people and should probably be closed down so another service that isn't fundamentally flawed can takes it's place.

Well, you're not wrong. There is a fairly strong case to be made that all IP law is morally wrong, and frankly the historical precedents regarding IP law,especially copyright, are particularly horrible. In short, current IP law is a blunt instrument that was created to serve a very narrow range of interests (and historically speak, *not* that of the creators). The rise of a truly global community and economy through the widespread deployment of the internet has only exacerbated those problems. 

YT & FB are effectively the court system for this new constituency and they are essentially tyrannical and opaque. I agree with you that they are merely responding to regulatory pressures from the legal entities which have granted their articles of incorporation. That doesn't change the fact that they function as a legal system unto themselves. Given that law is a combination of explicitly codified and customary behavior (as should be obvious to anyone living under a common-law system), I do feel that there is a certain burden of reformation on the publishing platforms as well. And handling the moral ambiguities of copyright is actual an ideal place for common-law solutions. 

Sadly, it seems that the platform corporations have little desire to use their deep financial power to support the creators who contribute to their success. Because they certainly *do* have enough financial power to bring lawsuit against Disney, UMG, and others like them in order to encourage creativity and regulate the apportionment of revenue from different uses of pre-existing content. But the platforms have essentially aligned themselves with the publishers who created copyright to protect their investment in printing presses. The concerns of creators have never been considered in copyright law, and likely never will.

The copyright length, bad as it is, is *exceptionally* ill suited to software (in particular, video games) and its' rapidly changing industry. You end up in a situation where software is "protected" by copyright when it has not been commercially available for decades, is not directly useable on any equipment (or operating system) that's still produced, and more than likely the current owner has no interest in making commercial use of the rights but is more than happy to enforce their ownership. 
The "best" solution there is probably to tie the length not to the date of creation but to the date of last commercial re-release (or sublicensing to a third party for publishing).

Largely dead on. There are a couple of issues with photography. The time, expense, and effort of a photographer has absolutely nothing to do with copyright. Only the creative elements of a photo are subject to copyright. Period.

Why is the photographer EXPECTED to be able to make money from that, let's face it, the world wouldn't end if "professional photographer" suddenly stopped existing as a job. The only reason that one group is protected, they have the right to a career in taking pictures of stuff, where as another group of people don't have that right to a career. I also agree on the main point of the ending. Copyright (and I'd add, patenting) is a mess. Even in and of itself it is questionable: a government-granted monopoly as a reward for innovation, is a monopoly nonetheless, and monopolies are easily misused. You make a very good point that it used to work (kinda) with big companies who can afford a legal team. And before that, it no doubt worked outright because the catalog was rather limited and lines were short.
.
But copyright doesn't work anymore. It stifles competition and innovation, and is just one of many avenues of eternal, ruinous lawsuits. When you need a lawyer to deal with it, as a regular person, the law is broken. And much of its application has nothing to do with its purpose.
.
From my understanding, in most media, the vast majority of sales are done in a matter of weeks. After that, anyone who wanted it, got it. Anyone who didn't yet get it, isn't willing or able to pay for it, so you won't miss any sales from them. Preventing them from copying your work (privately) does not benefit the copyright holder, and merely makes sure to deprive the poor from access to culture, prevents further innovation based on your idea,  and prevents your art from reaching a much larger audience. I see no benefit to this.
.
I dare say, the onus is on the copyright holders to explain why we should violate our core principles of freedom by granting them exclusivity, at all. There are cases where it's valuable. By all means, I don't want people profiting off ripping off someone else's work. Those who made it, deserve the paycheck. Perhaps use in formal publications should require permission, and commercial use should always be credited. But as a rule, it seems to me, you miss no sales, and society as a whole benefits, from most forms of copying. 
(and if someone gets DMCA''ed to shut up their criticism.. in my personal opinion, clear abuse of law to do harm upon others, is a crime against justice itself, and a hanging is in order ^_^)

The sad truth is that ENTIRE COPYRIGHT SYSTEM IS BASED ON A LIE AND IS NOW CRACKED AT ITS VERY CORE.

We are being told that if we come up with the idea then we own the idea just like one owns a car or a bike. THAT IS A LIE. An idea is no property. Because what if two people came up with the same idea at the same time? Legal system only allows one of them to own said idea - then the other is basically robbed of his property. That situation is impossible in case of owning a physical object because by default two people simply cannot buy one and the same car without knowing about it.

Hence why the very concept of "owning" an idea is fundamentally unjust. 

Also the reason why copyright law was introduced is because it was widely believed that if people cannot forever benefit from what they came up with then they would lose interest in innovation. But this mindset was proven wrong on many occasions. Biggest inventors were typically robbed of their inventions by clever bastards who knew their way around the law. Look no further than Nikola Tesla vs Thomas Edison. Actually copyright law doesn't encourage progress but hinders it. Progress is mostly ensured by freedom of taking other people's work and improve it, making it even better. But entire copyright and patent system makes it very, very difficult.

You claim that if small youtuber uses copyrighted content than ppl tend to just smile but if an international corporation used content from small youtuber than it would be a big deal. What absurd thing to claim! Small artists were robbed time and time again by the big players. There were many cases when big artists landed international hit songs and later it was revealed that big parts of said songs were copies of unknown artists' work. Nothing ever came out of it because a small artist is powerless against famous pop and rock stars protected by large international music studios.

Current copyright and patent law only protects large players leaving them completely in control as small artists simply can't afford the lawyers. The world however becomes more and more decentralized. Programmers no longer need international corporations to make server OS like GNU Linux or office software like LibreOffice. Many fan productions rival million dollar films in terms of quality.

A lot of great quality products, movies and music could be available if not for ancient copyright law that keeps small group of VIPs in position of power not allowing people with great a chance to compete.

I agree that it's a good system for the most part, but I think it's the edge cases that make it break down sometimes. One channel I follow (Adam Neely) got his video demonetised because a representative from a media company filed a manual copyright claim for a song that the company had lost the copyright to in court, so they had no legal grounds with which to file the claim. Another one (Street French) got their video demonetised because they mentioned COVID-19, and in YouTube's opinion, earning ad revenue from a video COVID-19 is somehow akin to profiting off people's deaths? (That seems absurd to me; the YouTubers are just sharing the reality of life that they're living, which is exactly what YouTube is supposed to be about.) I suppose that isn't a copyright claim, though.

So yes, Tom, while I agree that a lot of people on YouTube use ignorance as an excuse to violate the law, the problem isn't so much what happens to people who are actually breaking copyright. The problem is how there's often no recourse for content creators who aren't actually breaking the law, unless they happen to have money and legal expertise in abundance to defend their cases.

Most people fundamentally misunderstand the purpose of Youtube's copyright system.  Youtube are not in the business of making judgments and ruling on disputes.  Youtube merely provide the mechanisms to process the copyright claims, facilitate takedowns and an appeals process that puts the two parties in touch with each other.  They expect content creators and copyright claimants to sort out disputes between themselves, employing legal means if need be.

Youtube takedown content when requested in order to avoid legal liability and will not rule on disputes for the same reason.

I tried to explain this on the Sargon V. Akilah Obviously lawsuit videos and my comment ended up deleted for some reason.  In the US you have to apply for US copyright protection on any piece of work you do, whether it's a song, a video for youtube or a picture you drew, and it costs money, tons of money. You don't get copyright protections just because you claim its copyrighted when it's really not and you have not went through the proper channels through the government to apply for copyright protection.  Youtube gave everyone a false sense of security for some reason, on how they handle copyright claims. If you don't have a real copyright and the paperwork to back that claim up, then the only protection you have is Youtube honoring in good faith your false claim that you have a copyright on something.  Once you put something up on the internet, no matter which site you put it up on, it's in the public domain. You are giving your work to the world to use as they want if you have not protected your work with a real copyright through the US government. Youtube only takes down material when someone claims a copyright because it doesn't have time to check every claim, and that's where the abuse comes from. You make a video and upload it to your Youtube channel, and you don't get an actual copyright protection for it, anyone can now use that video or take that video and get a copyright for it, and once that happens they can legally profit off of it without worry of you, the original creator, of suing them because they now hold the copyright to something that you gave away to the public domain and there is nothing you can do about it.

I am legit that person who is watching a Let's Play of a game like Pokemon or Animal Crossing while currently playing Pokemon or Animal Crossing, while sitting on the alternate version of Pokemon I haven't played yet because I will start a Nuzlocke on that game. While some people will watch Let's Plays and not play the game because of it, others who cannot afford the game at the time may fall in love with it and get it later, or one of the "sequels". There are also people that will buy games because they think they can play it better than the Youtuber or Streamer they were watching. 
I would love to see some raw data analysis. When you look at the pure numbers for units sold of Pokemon care series games, as an example, Diamond/Pearl sold 17.67 million copies in/around 2006, before people were widely uploading Pokemon content and Let's Plays. Pokemon Sun/Moon sold 16.18 million copies, and that game also tried an entirely new set up. Following that, Ultra Sun/Moon which had very, very little in the way of difference, sold another 8.77 million copies. And Pokemon Sword/Shield sold 17.37 million copies. Consider the wide range of video games available to people today, I do not think it is streamers and youtubers that are to blame for revenue loss. It's too much saturation of the same things, and _critic_ of poor games being incredibly immediate, visual, and passionate. A video review of a top hyped game that just destroys it is going to do so much more damage than someone doing a let's play and enjoying it. Hell, it's not like Pokemon cares. They know they hooked enough of us at 12 that they are going to have us buying both versions of every core series game they put out until we die. 
It's when Mass Effect Andromedas and Anthems come out as rushed, garbage and get ripped to shreds and the companies can't trick people into buying their buggy ass, unfinished game for more than a week that loses them buyers, and future customers. But of course the idiots in the industry would rather blame people for playing their games online than making polished, finished games, and releasing them when they are actually finished, and not jumping on fads that will be over before the morons are even half way through their slapped together clone.

Big companies (with names like ones that start with "Dis" and end in "ney") have been stealing from the public domain for decades. Copyright was originally designed to be a compromise: the government saw benefit in protecting people's right to profit off their own work, but it also saw that it needed to protect the right of the public to eventually use preceding work freely, because letting companies hold intellectual property forever stifles creativity. The public domain was an integral part of the compromise. But companies have lobbied to continually change copyright law so that their big moneymakers will never enter the public domain. They've effectively stolen these works from the public domain.

In the past I have used an original song in the background of a video, that song was published by the original author under a Creative Commons licence. Many years later the video got claimed by some record label. I can only assume the artist had signed a deal with them. I responded with a copy of the licence that I held, as well as a hyperlink to where that media was still being distributed by the artist under that Creative Commons licence. That bit about Mystery Science Theater 3000 isn't quite right. The show didn't license the movies, the movies were licensed by the TV channel they were airing on. That was one of the main selling points of the show when they were pitching it to the network. The movies had already been licensed to fill broadcast gaps, like super late at night or on holidays. So the show was incredibly cheap to make. It was like those movie marathons channels sometimes had, with a hoast's commentary bookending all the ad breaks... accept it went through the whole show. This is why it was so hard to get the MST3K episodes released on VHS or DVD when home video became a thing. In order to release an episode you had to re-license the movie that was featured.

The US Constitution specifies: to the creator, for limited times. Once it's past the creator's death, it's infinite from the creator's perspective, so those statutes are legally void on their face.  The people who wrote that rule set the term to seven years, renewable once for another seven.  That's plenty.  If you're a rock star, write good song at least every 14 years.  Garage Band and ProTools have replaced studios for new bands so as costs fall so should protection terms.  The insane corporate racket terms weren't a thing until the 1950's.  This nonsense about "nostalgia cycles" is the time when the culture should be remixing and reimagining, not coughing up money for a few day's work somebody did forty years ago.  We give them temporary protection, at our cost, for the return of the works entering the public domain. In the interest of fixing the system it's trying to work around, copyright is a fix to work around the system of capitalism. People need money to survive, so under that system it makes sense that they should be able to get money from their work and have the rights to that work. But that system itself doesn't have to be the way the world works. People shouldn't have to have money to survive, that should just be a basic human right. Everyone should have the right to a decent life, it shouldn't have to be earned, you shouldn't have to work to survive, working under threat of death is in essence a form of normalized slavery, and I truly believe we have the resources to make that better world happen, if only corporate interests and propaganda weren't out to convince everyone a better world isn't possible so they can stay in power, with arbitrary ideas of some magical concept of unavoidable "human nature", the assertion that every other system is somehow even worse, the idea that someone can "earn" massive amounts of wealth as though they alone are responsible and the many workers that helped to make it happen aren't worth any more than minimum wage, all these ideas in the public consciousness to perfectly justify rich people and corporations being able to control the world while billions live in poverty and suffer. People shouldn't need to make money, and in a world where people don't need to make money, copyright doesn't need to exist. That's how you fix the underlying system.

We should abolish the concept of intellectual property (except as it can be cobbled from other property-rights and the right to make contracts and have them enforced against signers AND third parties)."Intellectual property" as it exists now is not a creation of market forces but is entirely a government creation. And the people who say "If we don't have any intellectual property, then the people who create new drugs to cure diseases, and the people who create valuable works of literature, drama, music, and imagery, and the people who invent machines to solve problems, all will receive no compensation for their toil and effort" are simply lying. There ARE other ways, especially in this age of cryptology and crowd-funding. And who thinks that inventors and scientists get compensation for their success anyway? They've signed away their Intellectual Property rights as a condition of being employed. The people who are reaping rewards are stockholders in corporations, not the people who do the work. It's just another scheme whereby the thing that makes entitled to "earn" vast amounts of money boils down to "already having money in excess of your needs". And your "deservingness" is proportion not to your acumen but to the amount of money you already have. Two shrewd investors may work in the exact same manner and employ the exact same diligence and conscientiousness to discover a stock that is going to double in value in six months. One of them has $1,000 to play with, and the other has $2,000 to play with. The latter will "earn" twice as much FOR THE SAME LABOR, DISCIPLINE, and THOROUGHNESS, and it won't be because his input was twice as meritorious. Rather, he's able to back THE SAME input with twice as much money. Who REALLY thinks that the latter investor "earns" twice as much, for the same work? We need to stop rewarding investors (meaning, stop "paying money not to investors but to investors' existing money") and start rewarding creators.

Hi Tom. 
As someone who has inherited copyright works of a writer and performer, I disagree that the length of copyright should be decreased. Because of giant corporations and their blatant use of strong arm legal tactics,  the amount of money that I receive from the royalties is small, does not take away the fact that it was a legacy handed down to me. 
If it was any other business where someone has spent their lives creating a thriving enterprise and was then only allowed to pass it onto their children for 70 years or 50 or 20 as you suggest and then the assets become public domain there would be outrage, but because it's the entertainment industry, it should be free.

Honestly I think copyright shouldn't apply to anyone with a small enough amount of exposure. It should only apply to people who have like 100k views or above. Otherwise it should be the wild west. Copyright shouldn't prevent creativity, and the internet should be a place of creativity above all else. Large media companies who want another couple million from the creative work they bought on bargain from a struggling artist can go screw themselves. The key here should be less legislation and restriction, reduce time before works move to public domain, and those with small audiences like community theaters and small youtube creators should be able to use what they want in the name of creativity. If they start making serious money on something, then that is a different discussion. Individuals who own copyright on their own creative works should get all their copyright revenue, but huge mega corps with CEOs earning 8 and 9 figure salaries who own an astronomical amount of copyrights they had no creative hand in actually making, and have draconian exploitative contracts with the actual creators of the content should have their cut heavily taxed, with the revenue from that tax going to national and local art and creative initiatives. Individuals should get paid for their work, huge companies whose entire purpose is to make money from someone else's work (and are the real copyright 'infringers' for that reason) should not. And that is what is truly infuriating about this whole situation. It isn't a problem that people want to make money from their work, it is that the only people who are actually benefiting from the current system are huge companies with tons of money and lots of lawyers, and not the people who actually contribute to the furthering of art, culture, and creative endeavors.

There's an alternative solution: Creative Commons (and copyleft more generally).  Instead of remixing the latest saccharine crap from Disney or shouty noise from [whichever rapster the kids are listening to this week], you can just use works licensed under terms that say "derivative works are allowed, but may only be distributed under this same licence".  And before you say "that couldn't possibly work", consider that _every image on Wikipedia_ (except for the handful of Public Domain ones) is used under a copyleft licence.


Of course, that means that you in turn can't demand royalties from other people using _your_ remix, which might suck if you're too unimaginative to think of any better method than bit-rent for making an income from your work.


Incidentally, if copyright were eternal, as you discuss at 33:25, then there wouldn't _be_ any Shakespeare to collect licence fees on, because Raphael Holinshed would have served the Bard a cease-and-desist.  (However, Luigi da Porto wouldn't have sued over _Romeo and Juliet,_ because Ovid's heirs would have sued _him_ for _Giulietta e Romeo_ being a blatant rip-off of _Pyramus and Thisbe._  Though Shakespeare might have gotten away with his use of _Pyramus and Thisbe_ in _Midsummer Night's Dream;_ it's parodic and at _least_ as transformative as MST3k.)

But everything you say is also true: the copyright law itself isn't on track with public opinion. That doesn't mean that public opinion is always right, but that doesn't mean that the law is right either. On top of that though, something even more important to take into consideration is the fact that the catholic restrictions and exceptions we have for copyright do not work anymore in the form that they are. The world keeps on going forward, with more forms of entertainment being born every few years and with laws taking a long time to be modified for those things specifically. This is why we, for better or worse, we have many grey areas for many things, one of them being the emulation of video games, their preservation online and its connection and affiliation with piracy. 



In the world where the internet is truly powerful and where everyone has access to everything, the copyright law has restrictions which often do not take place and are dismissed completely. There's no proper security measures for copyright holders and it's confusing whether or not something is right or not. 



So, until someone does something about that and makes compromises that help people use content freely _under specific and correct restrictions_ AND help copyright holders not be in risk, this is always going to be a taboo situation.

I never understood how it was either legal or ethical for copyright extensions to steal from the public (domain) for the benefit of, mostly, corporations far removed from the actual creative work. Each and every one of us is the victim of theft; we are being deprived  of the value we would have derived from that material being free to use, and each day there are new offenses as works that otherwise would have entered the public domain are diverted, the ill-gotten gains of political lobbyists.

It seems to me that any past sale of copyright can now be revisited if the term of rights was stated (or even implied) to be the default term in force at the time. I think it plausible that a creator (especially one motivated less by profit and more by seeking the widest reach) would only accept the restrictions on duplication sold to a publisher as a *temporary, defined* means to that end. For the present rights holder to assert that copyright extension applies alters the thing sold (the rights) beyond recognition and to me that would void the entire contract. I'm speaking of an ideal world, not the illegitimate mess of legislation we are presently burdened with. I'm obviously not a lawyer as I possess common sense and don't want the mess to continue to the benefit of the legal profession (which is simultaneously the oldest profession, the two being essentially the same).

The court rulings "although sparce" DO allow for a lot of the stuff you claimed was illegal. You even showed the H3 case, but kind of skipped over the more detailed breakdown of why it was legal. The weight of each of the categories is not even, and those categories are all that matters. Most importantly are monetary effect and market replacement. For example: H3 pauses the video every few seconds, providing commentary which is frequently nothing more than jokes. The way you described it simply making jokes "is not criticism and review" but that's exactly the way H3 argued their case, the jokes count as criticism and the work counted as transformative. The original clip being played is not replaced by the reaction video because the point of the original video is sufficiently disrupted by the reaction, so you don't get the same experience watching the original video as watching the reaction video.

A question raised by this that I'm never sure about is how the law determines what constitutes a lost sale.  Is the assumption that anyone who watches a YouTube video of someone playing a video game is a potential paying consumer of that video game?  I can see why it might be, but I would argue that it's unlikely that that is actually the case.  If I watch 100 videos of gameplay from different games today, am I meaningfully depriving 100 game companies of potential revenue... given that there's no way I was going to buy 100 games in one day?

The conceit seems to be that anyone who gets your product for free is a potential paying customer.  But businesses use loss-leaders as an enticement to buy other products all the time.  So I'd argue that it's not that simple.

About what we should do to fix it. I agree that the length of copyright is a serious problem. But why should the age of the work be the determining factor? This entire discussion is, at its core, a question of how much profit is too much. Why not make copyright apply for as long as a work has generated less than ten thousand dollars (or an equivalent amount taking into account inflation, and obviously differing but similarly-culturally-significant amounts in other currencies) in profit for any persons or organizations who have held the rights to the work? In order to prove infringement, a claimant would need to prove that the total profit from the work is under the threshold. Yes, that would require effort, presumably mostly in recordkeeping. But I'm not sure it's any more effort than is required to prove infringement now. I'm also not sure if it's any less or the same, someone would probably need to do a feasibility study.

I'm of the opinion that profit is a harmful concept, and thus copyright is a harmful concept, and thus neither should exist, and from each according to their ability to each according to their needs, yadda yadda yadda. But I recognize the necessity of copyright to get something resembling fairness in our capitalist, profit-driven world. Perhaps if people's basic needs were more secure, this would be less of an issue.

There's one simple thing that would fix a lot of problems with the false copyright strikes on Youtube. They shouldn't pay any ad revenue to any party before the appeal has been handled. Sure they could play the ads, but give the revenue retroactively to the one who ultimately wins the dispute. If the company giving the copyright notice is correct, they'll get their money, but if the notice is false, they can't steal the money from the content creator for the time frame the video gets most of its views.

Some of these "criticism and review" segments with the boilerplates still feel like a gray area, or at least in a sense misleading to the audience. For instance, the reason you were able to confidently use the Baby Yoda gif was because it had already become clear that Disney was not going to litigate it, not because you gave a 3 second critique of it whose substance was unrelated to the rest of the video (only the fact of its delivery). And the reason you were able to confidently use the clip of Untitled Goose Game is because showing a clip of a few seconds of a video game is not substantial, and the copyright owner has always allowed far more substantial gameplay footage in the past (including thousands of full playthroughs). But if you actually did make a video that was just about showing off copyrighted works and interspersing hurried two-sentence critiques, that probably would not be fair use.

Great video!  A couple of comments:
1) The orphaned works problem is a real pity, _no_ _one_ benefits from that situation.  One
      class of proposed solutions that I like is to require copyright owners to pay a nominal
      fee or file a form perhaps every few years to keep a copyright in force.  If a work is in
      in active use, the copyright will be maintained.  If it is truly abandoned it will become public
2) Content ID is interesting.  This reminds me of patent pools, though not quite the same.
3) I agree that having a huge disconnect between the law and actual practise is an
    immense problem.  In effect, it gives enormous discretionary power to whoever has
    enough cash to hire tons of lawyers.  Not a good situation.  Regrettably, I doubt that this
    is going to get better during my lifetime.  The trend, in criminal law as well as IP law, has
    been in the opposite direction.

You were making a good argument until the end when you said that shortening the copyright term would only affect a few hundred people who were relying on their one hit for retirement. It takes a lifetime of training and dedication to became a songwriter or musician. One-hit wonders don't happen by accident usually. They happen because one person spent his life writing song after song after song and just by chance one of them got recorded and made a hit. That's not just a few hundred people. That's the vast majority of the music business. It takes thousands of people churning away making failed songs for society as a whole to benefit from the froth that all that churning creates for the really good stuff to be made. If you don't let one hit wonders and failed songwriters have a chance at making a decent living on what they spend their lives doing, then they won't engage in all that churn, and the level of froth will drop. Quality will drop, variety will drop, innovation will come slower. When creativity becomes something only hobbyists with another source of income can do, rather than a possible profession, then we will all suffer as a society. I say, yes, shorten the copyright term, but no shorter than the lifetime of the original creator.

Sorry but I'm not sure if this is because of you google affiliation, but the idea that it is a 2 way choice between lawsuit or copyright strike is ludicrous. This video to me echoes the misinformation (which was at the time mostly peddled by YouTube) around the EU's copyright directive, which seeks to solve exactly this issue by introducing a responsibility to negotiate license access on behalf of it's creators. This means that there is no longer the current level of power asymmetry that we are seeing with your proposed lawsuit/copyright strike issue. I wish people would pay more attention to it. This is not a matter of self regulation, and it is not an issue with the copyright system itself (that has existed long before lawyers and multinational organisations were seeking to vigorously enforce it) but it is a question of effective regulation which places a fair burden on those who profit the most. In this case that is YouTube, Facebook, and all the other hosting companies.

On the topic of public domain compositions, they themselves are a bit of a minefield. If a transcriber has made modifications to the original music, their version of the sheet music might be a transformative/derivative work. Music books are copyrighted, how do you know that music you're playing of a composer that died two centuries ago is public domain? And don't get me started on the ridiculous issue of potentially needing a reproduction license for sheet music if you're recording a performance and your camera angle catches the squiggly lines.
